abstract.text: An object that encapsulates the parameters to create a real-time or turn-based match.

inlineContent.text: To request a match, set the properties of the match request, such as the number of players, the invitation message, and whether to use automatch to fill the player slots. Youâ€™re required to set the minimum and maximum number of players allowed in the match. Then, pass the match request to the appropriate class, depending on the type of game and whether you implement your own user interface.
To use the matchmaking user interface that GameKit provides, pass the match request to the
class for real-time games, or the
class for turn-based games. GameKit sends messages to the delegates of these classes when players receive and accept invitations to the match.
If you implement your own interface for finding players, pass the match request to the
class for real-time games, or the
class for turn-based games. If the player selects the other players to invite in your interface, set the

You can refine the match results and reduce player wait times by configuring matchmaking before you present an interface. You can either find players using matchmaking rules you set up on the server, or find players from a subset of players you specify in the game.
To use matchmaking rules, set the
property to the queue name that you configure in App Store Connect. Optionally, set
to game-specific criteria. Players in the
property need to also be in the
property â€” that is, be a recipient of an invitation. When using matchmaking rules, Game Center ignores the subset that you specify using the
properties, use values that are in the rule setâ€™s player range. Otherwise, the default values for these properties are the rule setâ€™s
If you donâ€™t use matchmaking rules, you can restrict finding players to a subset of players. Set the
properties to specify the subset. Then matchmaking ignores the rules-based
Matchmaking rules are only available for peer-to-peer (

abstract.text: Create a rule set to contain matchmaking rules and teams.
Create a more customized and optimized gaming experience by using matchmaking rules to find players in a real-time game.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An invitation to join a match sent to the local player from another player.
A protocol that handles invite events from Game Center.
A playerâ€™s response to an invitation to join a match.
Possible responses from an invitation to a remote player.
A peer-to-peer network between a group of players that sign into Game Center.
A type for game-specific properties that Game Center uses to find players when using matchmaking rules.
An object that encapsulates the parameters to create a real-time or turn-based match.
The default number of players for the match.
The message sent to other players when the local player invites them to join a match.
Handles when a player responds to an invitation.
The maximum number of players that can join the match.
Returns the maximum number of players allowed in the match request for a given match type.
The minimum number of players that can join the match.
A mask that specifies the role that the local player would like to play in the game.
A number identifying a subset of players invited to join a match.
A list of player identifiers for players to invite to the match.
The criteria for the local player that Game Center uses to find other players when using matchmaking rules.
The name of the queue that Game Center places the match request in.
The criteria for recipients of the match request that Game Center uses to find other players when using matchmaking rules.
A method that handles when a player responds to an invitation to join a match.
The players to invite to the match.
A Boolean value that determines whether a game uses automatch to find players or the local player invites players.
The kind of match managed by Game Center.
A match hosted on your private server.
A turn-based match hosted by Game Center.
An object that creates matches with other players without presenting an interface to the players.
An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a real-time game and automatch to fill any empty slots.
An object that encapsulates the match data for games where players take turns.
An interface that allows a player to invite other players to a turn-based match and automatch to fill any empty slots.
Enable players to voice chat with all, or groups of, players in a multiplayer game.

abstract.text: Set criteria for assigning players to teams in your game using matchmaking rules.

abstract.text: Develop games where multiple players interact in real time.
Send data between players in a real-time multiplayer game.

abstract.text: Discover and invite other players to participate in a real-time game.

doc://com.apple.gamekit/documentation/Ga.title: Finding multiple players for a game

abstract.text: Create a more customized and optimized gaming experience by using matchmaking rules to find players in a real-time game.
Add a rule to find players in a range of skill levels to balance competitive gameplay.

doc://com.apple.gamekit/documentation/Ga.title: Finding players with similar skill levels

abstract.text: Game Center applies different type of rules you create in a particular order to find the best matches.
Let Game Center store and forward match data between players in a turn-based game.

doc://com.apple.gamekit/documentation/Ga.title: Starting turn-based matches and passing turns between players

abstract.text: Investigate issues with Game Center by evaluating your matchmaking rules using metrics endpoints.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
